For this week, I chose to take on the question: “Before 1 July 2018, will Ashraf Ghani cease to be president of Afghanistan?”  I am predicting and assigning a valuation of 3% that this event will occur.  The low probability of this event occurring is based upon several factors.  The event has only about 4 months and 1 week to occur.  Ashraf Ghani has been president of Afghanistan since 2014 and does not seem to be interested in stepping down voluntarily or due to a democratic election.  Afghanistan’s Independent Election Commission announced that the country will hold its parliamentary and district council elections on 7 July 2018, which is 6 days after the 1 July 2018 deadline in the question.  Also, this proposed election is scheduled to take place 3 years past the expiration of the sitting parliament’s 5-year mandate.  A reshaping of the parliament and district councils could factor into Ghani’s decision to step down, but in the unlikely event that it even takes place, it will occur after the deadline in the question.  Historically, elections in Afghanistan face major hurdles and difficulties due to declining security and safety in many parts of the country.  The political instability and the public’s insecurity will likely derail the parliamentary election, which undoubtedly will result in Ghani’s power grip on the Afghani presidency.  Ghani is a slow reformer and takes many actions that may be deemed as autocratic in nature, which impede the opposition to form and contest the government’s power.
In order to answer this question, we have to consider the flashpoints that could lead to him ceasing to be president prematurely.
